Award.AwardTitle: Hybrid organic-inorganic metal-semiconductor nanoparticles for highly efficient solar cell concentrators

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches
The objective of this research is to investigate theoretically the down-conversion of light in hybrid organic-inorganic metal-semiconductor nanoparticles, containing organic chromophores attached to semiconductor nanocrystals with metallic structures. The approach is to use time-dependent density-functional theory and finite-difference time domain techniques, with main purpose to identify, engineer, and model highly efficient luminescent solar cell concentrators.

Intellectual Merit
The intellectual merit is to understand thoroughly the physical mechanism of the down-conversion process in hybrid nanoparticles, which is essential for the optimal solar energy concentration. The reason for including metallic structures is to make use of the giant local electric field enhancement through plasmonic resonances of metallic nanostructures to increase the down conversion rate and therefore also the solar power gain.

Broader Impacts
The proposed activity will provide outreach programs through all educational levels, ranging from K-12 to undergraduate and graduate programs. For example, outreach to K-12 will be accomplished through regular participation at the Orlando Science Center. Being diverse will be a priority effort through encouraging women and underrepresented minority groups to participate in the proposed research and education programs.
The goal of the proposed research activity is to at least triple the concentration efficiency of existing luminescent solar energy concentrators, thereby reducing the costs of photovoltaic cells significantly, which will encourage many more people to install photovoltaic systems in their own homes, making US less dependent on foreign oil and at the same time supporting the environment and nature through a clean energy source.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals were to develop theoretical methods and perform calculations to engineer nanoparticles (NPs) for efficient down-conversion of light in luminescent solar cell concentrators (LSCC), to understand correlations among excitons in semiconductor materials, and to understand the effect of defects in semiconductor materials.

For that we investigated several materials, such as hybrid organic-inorganic materials made of TiO2/APTMS/folic acid nanoparticles, disordered GaAs quantum wells, 3D topological insulators, and single-layer MoS2.

In order to understand the fundamental process of downconversion in hybrid organic-inorganic materials, we calculated the photoluminescence of folic acid molecule attached to TiO2 nanoparticles. The down-conversion process can be used to down-convert solar photons to longer wavelengths, in order to trap them inside a waveguide. Our results are crucial for the development of luminescent solar energy concentrators based on hybrid organic-inorganic materials. We performed our numerical analysis in collaboration with the experimental groups of Sudipta Seal and Andre Gesquiere, who performed the experiments here at the University of Central Florida. Our results have been published in ACS Nano.

In order to understand exciton-exciton correlations, we formulated a time-dependent density-matrix functional theory (TDDMFT) approach to study higher-order correlation effects like biexcitons in optical processes in several bulk systems and nanostructures. Our approach is based on the reduced two-particle density-matrix formalism within the normal orbital representation.  In order to test the theory, we applied our method to calculate the lowest biexcitonic energies for several semiconductors – CdS, ZnO, CuCl and CuBr in the case of local single-particle and two-particle XC potentials. We have reproduced the experimental values for the biexcitonic binding energies by using proper values of the parameters for the exchange correlation potentials. These results have been published in Phys. Rev. B.

In collaboration with Sudipta Seal’s group we investigated the increase in the photocurrent for a standard silicon PV system coated with a TiO2/APTMS/folic acid thin film. In order to obtain accurate results over a broad wavelength regime, we calculated the dipole moments of TiO2/APTMS/folic acid over the whole Brillouin zone. We then used these results to calculate the conductivity tensor, which we needed to solve Maxwell’s equations for computing the transmission of solar light through the thin film to the silicon solar cell. The photocurrent was calculated using standard formulas and is in excellent agreement with the increased photocurrent observed in the experiment. These results provide the evidence of our proposed scheme for increasing of light-harvesting efficiency of standard silicon PV systems. The key outcome is that our results suggest that it is possible to coat any commercially available solar cell with TiO2/APTMS/folic acid thin film to increase the efficiency of solar energy harvesting. Our results will lead to a simple technology with the idea that every existing solar cell will be spray-painted with our thin film to increase the efficiency of solar energy harvesting.

In order to understand how defects affect the performance of 2D materials, we have demonstrated that the electrical property of single-layer molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) can be significantly tuned from the semiconducting to the insulating regime via controlled exposure to oxygen plasma. The mobility, on-current and resistance of single-layer MoS2 devices were varied by up to four orders of magnitude by controlling the plasma exposure time. Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and density functional theory studies suggest that the significant variation of electronic properties is caused by the creation of insulating MoO3-rich disordered domains in the MoS2 sheet upon oxygen plasma exposure, leading to an exponential variation of resistance and mobility as a function of plasma exposure time. The resistance variation calculated using an effective medium model is in excellent agreement with the measurements. These results have been published in Nanoscale.

By creating defects via oxygen plasma treatment, we demonstrate optical properties variation of single-layer MoS2. We found that, with increasing plasma exposure time, the photoluminescence (PL) evolves from very high intensity to complete quenching, accompanied by gradual reduction and broadening of MoS2 Raman modes, indicative of distortion of the MoS2 lattice after oxygen bombardment. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study shows the appearance of the Mo6+ peak, suggesting the creation of MoO3 disordered regions in the MoS2 flake. Finally, using band structure calculations, we demonstrate that the creation of MoO3 disordered domains upon exposure to oxygen plasma leads to a direct-to-indirect bandgap transition in single-layer MoS2, which explains the observed PL quenching. These results have been published in J. Phys. Chem.
